newsitem.title: HUNGARY: ING Barings raises EPSs of six Hungarian companies.
newsitem.headline: ING Barings raises EPSs of six Hungarian companies.

text.p: ING Barings raised its 1997 earnings per share (EPS) forecast for six Hungarian companies, the securities house said in the February issue of its Eastern European Monthly.

ING Barings' analyst team upgraded its earlier forecasts for brewery Sopron, plastics group Pannonplast, chemicals Borsodchem, pharmaceuticals Richter, home improvement product maker Graboplast and hotelier Danubius.
It also modified its recommendation for all six stocks.
Sopron's 1997 EPS was raised to 549 forints from the previously forecast 453 forints, ING Barings said, adding "we expect EPS to double as Sopron absorbs Martfu's operation."

Austria's Brau Union, majority owner of both Soproni and Martfu, said in January it would merge its two Hungarian units and made a buyout offer to all Martfu shareholders at 206 Austrian schillings per share.

Pannonplast's 1997 EPS forecast was increased to 464 forints from 439 forints, on planned capacity increases in four of the group's subsidiaries, quality change in product mix and a possible acquisition.
Borsodchem's EPS was raised to 989 forints from 810 forints, ING Barings said, adding that the company is likely to get a 100 percent tax holiday in 1997.
Ratings of each of Sopron, Pannonplast and Borsodchem were raised to 'buy' from 'long-term buy.'
Whereas Richter's recommendation was reduced to 'long-term buy' from 'buy' despite a rise in its 1997 EPS to 778 forints from 749 forints on "stockpiling ahead of drug price rises in January."

"At the same time multiples at Richter are quite demanding such as EV/EBIDTA...that's the reason why ING Barings changed its recommendation to 'long-term buy' from 'buy'" Gabor Sitanyi, ING Barings' analyst in London, told Reuters.
Danubius's EPS was raised to 277 forints from the previously planned 266 forints on "better than expected occupancy rates and delayed financing costs attached to the Hungaria deal."
Danubius's rating was modified to 'hold' from 'long-term buy' for two reasons, Sitanyi said.
"We didn't fully believe that the assets valuation argument is sustainable including the refurbishment costs at Hungaria (Hotels)," he said.
"The other reason was that we expect earnings being depressed over the next six months due to financing and refurbishment costs of Danubius's latest acqusition," he said.
ING Barings hiked Graboplast's EPS to 437 forints from 381 forints saying it will benefit from a weaker mark.
"Stronger than expected margins as a result of a weak German mark, although the chemicals cycle is likely to work somewhat against the group in 1997," ING Barings said.
Graboplast's recommendation was changed to 'long-term buy' from 'buy'.
"We don't expect the company to come to the market for new money and EPS growth is still going to be sustainably high," Sitanyi said.
